Not dramatically—he's too practiced for that—but the benevolent mask relaxes slightly, revealing something sharper and more genuine beneath.

exchanges.speaker: francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: You wish me to educate you. Very well, Your Majesty. I will speak more frankly than I had intended. I have been Bishop of Barcelona for eleven years. In that time, I have watched three popes, two antipopes, a council that nearly tore Christendom apart, and a king of Aragon who visits his kingdom perhaps once every three years. I have learned to be... cautious. About what I say. To whom I say it. But you bring your queen. You speak of listening. You reference Her Majesty the regent with respect. And you have the favor of Pope Eugenius, which is not nothing in these times. So. Frankly.

exchanges.speaker: francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: There are three concerns that keep Aragonese churchmen awake at night, Your Majesty. I will name them. First: the Military Orders. You now control Santiago, Calatrava, and Alcántara by papal decree. The masters answer to Castile's crown. These orders have commanderies in Aragon. They hold lands, collect revenues, wield influence. When Aragonese clergy look at what happened in Castile, they wonder: are we next? Will Your Majesty seek similar authority over institutions that have traditionally answered to... other powers? Second: appointments. The bishops of Castile are, increasingly, men who align with royal interests. This is natural—kings prefer cooperative clergy. But Aragon has its own traditions. The Cathedral Chapter of Barcelona has elected its own bishops for centuries. If 'unity' means Castilian influence over Aragonese appointments—if Toledo begins to speak for Barcelona—there will be resistance. Quiet resistance, perhaps. But real. Third: Basel. Your Majesty supported Pope Eugenius against the Council. This was wise—Eugenius prevailed, and you have his gratitude. But some Aragonese clergy supported the Council's reforms. They believed—still believe—that the Church needs change, that papal authority has grown too absolute, that councils should check papal power. These men are not heretics. They are not your enemies. But they wonder if Your Majesty's closeness to Eugenius means they will be... remembered. Punished. Passed over for preferment because they chose the wrong side in a dispute that is supposedly resolved.

exchanges.speaker: francesc_climent_sapera
exchanges.text: These are the concerns, Your Majesty. Spoken plainly, as you requested. Now. You said you wished to address them if within your power. I am listening. What does the Conqueror of Granada, the Champion of Constantinople, the man who speaks of the kingdom of heaven—what does he say to a tired bishop who worries about the Church he has spent his life serving?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Grant you blessing from the lord sir. When we open our hearts and step into the light, we serve the lord. It's what I have always tried to do. And let me thank you for being so open. Let me first address your concern about military orders. I seek not to establish more control over other institutions of the church. And I can add that the current arrangement was done with total mutual agreement and cooperation. The military orders were left without a purpose after the reconquista so we have found a new way, a new goal to set our sights to. If the masters of the orders were here, they would tell you that the arrangement is mutually beneficial. They have gained a new purpose and I have granted them even more lands in Granada as well. In short, the situation with the military orders are unique, I do not seek to acquire other institutions and I now and always seek to cooperate with the church and its institutions.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia meet with Bishop Francesc Climent Sapera of Barcelona in the Palau Reial. The bishop initially probes diplomatically about Juan's 'unity' speech, but Juan's respectful approach encourages frank discussion. The bishop reveals three major Aragonese Church concerns: fears about royal control over institutions following the Military Orders precedent, worries about Castilian influence over traditional Aragonese episcopal appointments, and anxiety among clergy who supported the Council of Basel. Juan begins addressing these concerns, starting with reassurances about the Military Orders being a unique situation born of mutual benefit rather than a template for broader church control.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: These are the concerns, Your Majesty. Spoken plainly, as you requested. Now. You said you wished to address them if within your power. I am listening. What does the Conqueror of Granada, the Champion of Constantinople, the man who speaks of the kingdom of heaven—what does he say to a tired bishop who worries about the Church he has spent his life serving?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me first address your concern about military orders. I seek not to establish more control over other institutions of the church. The military orders were left without a purpose after the reconquista so we have found a new way. The situation with the military orders are unique, I do not seek to acquire other institutions and I now and always seek to cooperate with the church. Your second issue touches on how bishops are elected. You may be pleased to learn that I have already openly committed to this position. Our Basel delegation is supporting this. I fully support that cathedral chapters elect their own bishops. And concerning your third issue, I support quite some reforms of the council. I feel like the church must reform and should also find a way to re-establish its authority and keep the church united. I support reforms and consider them essential to prevent another schism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia reaches into the document case she carries and produces a sealed letter, heavy parchment bearing both the Castilian arms and the Imperial eagle.

exchanges.speaker: lucia
exchanges.text: We have a copy, caro. Though perhaps His Excellency should see the summary of positions rather than the personal correspondence?

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: You travel with Imperial correspondence. And your queen knows which documents to produce. You are better prepared than most kings who claim to be 'listening and learning,' Your Majesty. Before I read, I must ask directly. Your Majesty has the favor of Pope Eugenius. You carry letters co-signed with the Emperor. You claim to support Council reforms while maintaining papal relationships. How? How does one hold both positions without being torn apart? One cannot serve two masters, Your Majesty. So tell me — which master do you actually serve?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The reality is indeed complicated. Fortunately, I can tell you that even the pope supports reforms and the council. I support both in a sense as the situation is nuanced.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan lifts the entire satchel and carries it to the bishop's writing desk, spreading documents across the polished wood. The Documents Revealed: The Declaration of Como signed by Emperor Sigismund and Juan, the Letter to Pope Eugenius IV proposing parallel legislation, the Castilian Delegation Instructions outlining support for reforms while maintaining neutrality on papal supremacy, and the Council of Basel Session 12 Decree on electoral reform.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I came to this meeting expecting diplomatic pleasantries. Perhaps some vague assurances. Instead you have shown me... everything. Your position. Your alliances. Your actual policy. Kings do not do this. Kings guard their positions, reveal nothing, commit to nothing until they have extracted maximum advantage. Why? Why show me all of this? What do you want from Barcelona's Church that is worth revealing your entire hand?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What do I want from you? I wish for Barcelona's church to bless marriages of devout Christians who live fruitful lives. I hope the church in Barcelona educates and tells the gospel with conviction. I hope that church generosity helps the poor. That the stories from the bible help guard against sin. I want us to do good. I truly believe that if we do, we walk in God's glory. I support these positions because I believe it best allows the church to do the things I just described. A unified and reformed church with elected bishops are in my opinion better equipped to bring us this. That is what I want.

roll.outcome: Deeply moved and convinced. The Bishop's cynicism crumbles in the face of Juan's genuine faith and comprehensive documentation. He becomes a strong ally.

encounters.recap: Juan addresses the Bishop's concerns about military orders, episcopal elections, and church reform by revealing his complete diplomatic position. He shows all documents including the Declaration of Como with Emperor Sigismund, correspondence with Pope Eugenius, and Basel delegation instructions. When asked what he wants from Barcelona's Church, Juan gives a deeply spiritual answer about doing good works and walking in God's glory. The Bishop's cynical expectations are completely overturned by Juan's transparency and genuine faith.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Why? Why show me all of this? What do you want from Barcelona's Church that is worth revealing your entire hand?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! What do I want from you? I wish for Barcelona's church to bless marriages of devout christians who life fruitfull lives. I hope the church in Barcelona educated and tells the gospel with conviction. I hope with all my heart that the confession services provided open hearts and lift spirits. That church generosity helps the poor. That the stories from the bible helps guard against sin. I want us to do good. I truly believe that if we do, we walk in God's glory. A slice of heaven here on earth, metaphorically speaking. I have pledged to fight for it and I will do so until my dying breath. I support these positions because I believe it best allows the church to do the things I just described. A unified and reformed church with elected bishops are in my opinion better equipped to bring us this. That is what I want. For doing good it is it's own reward.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bishop is silent for a long moment. He looks down at the documents spread across his desk—the Declaration of Como with its Imperial seal, the reform positions, the twenty-three pages of electoral decree. Then he looks back at Juan. Something shifts in his face. The politician recedes. What remains is older, more tired, more human.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. May I speak to you not as Bishop of Barcelona to King of Castile, but as... as a priest? As a man who took vows forty years ago and has spent most of that time forgetting why?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He doesn't wait for permission. He rises from his desk and moves to the window, looking out at the unfinished cathedral—the scaffolding, the half-completed spires reaching toward heaven.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: I was twenty when I entered the Church. I believed... I believed what you just said. That the Church existed to do good. To marry the faithful, educate the young, comfort the dying, feed the hungry. I believed that if we did these things, we walked in God's glory. A slice of heaven on earth.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Do you know what forty years of church politics does to that belief, Your Majesty? It doesn't kill it quickly. That would be merciful. It kills it slowly. One compromise at a time. One appointment made for political reasons rather than pastoral ones. One reform delayed because the timing wasn't right. One principle set aside because the greater good required flexibility.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He returns to his chair, sitting heavily.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: I have not thought about why I became a priest in... I cannot remember how long. Years, perhaps. I think about revenues and appointments and factions and which cardinal to cultivate and which bishop to avoid. I think about Barcelona's position relative to Tarragona, about the chapter's privileges, about protecting what we have built.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: And then a king walks into my study, shows me everything—everything—and when I ask what he wants, he tells me he wants the Church to bless marriages and teach the gospel and hear confessions and feed the poor. I had forgotten that was the point. Do you understand? I had forgotten that was the point.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: I have met many kings, Your Majesty. I have met kings who wanted Church lands, Church gold, Church influence. I have met kings who wanted bishops in their pockets and abbots who would bless their wars. I have met kings who spoke of God while reaching for power, who wrapped their ambitions in holy language. I have never met a king who wanted what you want. Who showed me his entire hand and asked for nothing except that I do my duty to God.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: You spoke last night of the kingdom of heaven. Of glimpsing it in moments—at Alcalá, at your daughter's birth. I confess I thought it was rhetoric. Beautiful words for a beautiful speech. I do not think it is rhetoric. I think you mean it. And I think... I think I have been waiting a very long time to meet a king who meant it.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: So let me tell you what I can offer in return—not as payment, but as... partnership. As a priest who has remembered, thanks to you, why he took his vows. First: I will write to the Archbishop of Tarragona and to the bishops of Girona, Vic, and Urgell. I will tell them what I have seen here today. Second: I will speak to the Catalan clergy about your Constantinople expedition. Not as a political venture, but as what it is—a crusade to defend Christendom. Third: When you return from Constantinople—when, Your Majesty, not if, for I will pray daily for your safe return—I will be here. And if your vision of unity between Castile and Aragon moves forward, you will find in Barcelona's Church not an obstacle but an ally.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He rises, and moves to stand before Juan.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_of_barcelona
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. I am too old and too tired to kneel easily. But will you permit an old priest to give you his blessing? Not a diplomatic blessing. A real one. For a man I believe is doing God's work.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would like to recieve your blessing father. And I am grateful for your support.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan kneels before him.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Before I leave, I would like to pray with you, or attend a mass that you are leading. I would love to see the priest at work who joined the church at twenty who believed.

roll.outcome: Spiritual Recognition: The bishop sees genuine faith in Juan that hasn't been corrupted by power. He responds as a priest rather than politician, sharing his own struggles and hopes for the Church. A true alliance forms rooted in shared faith.

encounters.recap: When Juan reveals he wants nothing from Barcelona's Church except for it to fulfill its spiritual mission, the Bishop experiences a spiritual awakening. The old priest remembers why he entered the Church forty years ago, admits he had forgotten the Church's true purpose amid decades of politics, and offers genuine partnership. He promises to write supportive letters to other Aragonese bishops, support the Constantinople expedition as a crusade, and provide blessed alliance when Juan returns. The meeting ends with Juan kneeling to receive the Bishop's genuine blessing and requesting to pray together or attend mass.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bishop looks down at Juan kneeling before him. For a moment, his hands tremble. This is not the ceremonial blessing he has given a thousand times to nobles seeking favor, to merchants wanting church approval for their ventures, to diplomats who needed the appearance of ecclesiastical support. This is something else. He places his hands on Juan's head. His voice, when it comes, is rougher than he intends.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: Benedictio Dei omnipotentis, Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti, descendat super te et maneat semper. May the Lord bless you and keep you. May He make His face to shine upon you, and be gracious unto you. May He lift up His countenance upon you, and give you peace. Go to Constantinople, Your Majesty. Defend the faith. And come home safely to your wife and your daughter and the kingdoms that need you.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His hands remain on Juan's head a moment longer than necessary. He withdraws his hands, and Juan rises. Then Juan speaks of prayer. Of Mass. Of seeing 'the priest who joined at twenty who believed.' The bishop's expression flickers — something crosses his face that he cannot quite hide. He turns away, moving back toward the window, and is quiet for a long moment. When he speaks, his voice is different. Smaller. Less certain.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: You ask to see a man I am not sure still exists, Your Majesty. I have said Mass thousands of times. Thousands. The words are... they are words now. I say them correctly. I perform the liturgy with precision. The faithful receive the sacrament and go home satisfied. But the priest who believed... he would have meant every word. He would have felt the presence of God in the bread and wine, not merely affirmed it doctrinally.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turns back to face Juan and Lucia.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: You have given me something today. Something I thought I had lost forever. But I cannot simply... become that man again in an afternoon. Faith is not a garment one puts on and takes off. I am afraid, Your Majesty. Afraid that if I try to pray with you as that young priest would have prayed, you will see what I fear is true — that he is gone, and only the politician remains wearing his vestments.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He spreads his hands — a gesture of helplessness from a man not accustomed to admitting helplessness.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: I will say Mass tomorrow morning. The Feast of... no, it is simply an ordinary day. An ordinary Mass for ordinary faithful. You are welcome to attend. You and the Queen. But I ask that you not expect... I ask that you understand I am only beginning to remember. I cannot promise that the priest who believed will be there. Only that I will try to find him. Is that enough? For a king who speaks of trying, who told his court that all we can do is try — is my trying enough?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But father, of course it is enough. It is always enough if we try. I think that God places obstacles on our path to test us sometimes. How we deal with them, we discover who we are. Do not put burden to perform on yourself father. Just try to reach for whatever inspires you and you may yet surprise others and yourself. We will see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia rises gracefully from her chair, smoothing her burgundy gown. Her eyes move between Juan and the bishop, and there is something soft in her expression—she has witnessed something unexpected this morning, and it has touched her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_aragon
exchanges.text: Your Excellency. Thank you for your honesty. It is... rarer than it should be.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. You have married a remarkable man. I suspect you already know this.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_aragon
exchanges.text: I am learning it. Day by day.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bishop walks them to the door of the reception chamber. At the threshold, he pauses.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: Tomorrow. The Mass will be at the hour of Terce—mid-morning. The Cathedral of Santa Eulàlia. It is not complete, but... perhaps that is fitting. Neither am I. I will not promise the priest who believed. But I will try not to be only the politician. It has been a very long time since anyone asked me to try.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He makes the sign of the cross over them both—a small gesture, almost reflexive, but genuine.

exchanges.speaker: bishop_barcelona
exchanges.text: Go with God, Your Majesties. I will see you tomorrow.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: As they walk, Lucia takes Juan's arm. She is quiet for a moment, then speaks softly.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_de_aragon
exchanges.text: That was not what I expected, caro. Not at all. You did something to that man. Something real. Is this what you meant, last night? About turning hearts through honesty? I have watched my father's court for twenty years. I have never seen a king do what you just did. Show everything. Ask for nothing. And receive... that.

encounters.recap: Juan receives a deeply personal blessing from the Bishop of Barcelona, who confesses his spiritual crisis and admits he no longer feels the faith he once had as a young priest. Juan's request to see 'the priest who believed' moves the bishop to vulnerability and self-reflection. The bishop invites them to Mass the next morning, promising to try to rediscover his lost faith.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And if you are uncertain what to say, you may wink at me. I will be watching. Now. Let us see what diplomatic crisis Catalina has created with the nursery staff.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I love you Lucia d'Este.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And I love you, Juan of Castile. Even when you swing your hammer at things that do not need hammering. Especially then.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: They find Catalina in a sunlit room overlooking a garden, surrounded by evidence of extensive negotiations. Donna Francesca sits in a chair with the expression of a woman who has been thoroughly outmaneuvered. A young Aragonese nursemaid hovers nearby, looking uncertain. On a small table sits an empty plate with suspicious crumbs. On another table sits a second empty plate with more suspicious crumbs. Catalina herself is on the floor, engaged in serious diplomatic discussions with a boy of perhaps four years — dark-haired, solemn-faced, dressed in fine clothes that mark him as noble-born. Between them are arranged several wooden animals, a small cloth ball, and what appears to be a torn piece of parchment that has been folded into something vaguely boat-shaped.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No. Bird goes here. Horse goes there. Is obvious.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: But the horse wants to be with the bird.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Horse is wrong.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Your Majesties. The princess has been... she has been very well-behaved. She has made a friend. This is young Lord Bernat, son of the Viscount of Cardona. His mother brought him to play while she attends the regent.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa! Mama! Catalina has a friend. His name is... His name is Boy.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: Bernat.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Ber-nat. Catalina taught him about horses. He did not know horses go there.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And how many crostatas did this important lesson require, piccola?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: One and a half. Like we agreed.

exchanges.speaker: donna_francesca
exchanges.text: Perhaps... perhaps there were two and a half, Your Majesty. The young lord was hungry, and the princess felt it was only fair to keep him company.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Fair. Company.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And has Catalina been good? Have you been playing nice with Bernat?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Catalina is always good.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: She took my horse. And she said birds are better than horses. And she said her papa conquered a whole kingdom and my papa only has a... A viscounty.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Horse was in the wrong place. And Papa did conquer a kingdom. Is true.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Lord Bernat. Did Catalina share her crostatas with you, at least?

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: She gave me half of one. She said it was generous.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Half. Catalina is very generous. Papa. Bernat does not know about rope. Or about the boy in the water. Should Catalina tell him?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Catalina, my daughter. It is always better to let others talk about the good things you did. And when we are with others, we always share with them equally as they share equally with us.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But... But if Catalina does not tell, how will Boy know?

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: Bernat.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: How will Bernat know?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Others will tell him, piccola. The story travels on its own. And when you do not tell it, but others do, it becomes even more... impressive.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: More impressive. Share... equally? Catalina had two. Bernat had half. That is not equal. But Catalina was hungry.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: She said she was a princess and princesses get more.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Maybe. Maybe Catalina gives Bernat a crostata next time.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maybe you can play that Bernat is the king, and you are a viscountess for a while no? See how you like it. We will be back in a short while love, me and Lucia have some boring stuff to do yet.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: But... But Catalina is a princess.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: And Bernat is a viscount's son. But in play, we can be anything. That is what makes it play.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: I could be king?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Bernat can be king. For a little while. And Catalina will be... Vis-coun-tess. But a very important viscountess. Who has a horse. And a bird. And the king listens to her advice because she is very smart.

exchanges.speaker: bernat
exchanges.text: Can the king have the horse?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: The king can borrow the horse. Because he is king. But the viscountess still owns it.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Have fun!

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: A very important viscountess. Who owns the horse but graciously allows the king to borrow it. I wonder where she learned to negotiate like that.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia visit the nursery where Catalina has been playing with young Lord Bernat. They discover she has been dominating their games and eating more than her share of treats. Juan teaches her about sharing equally and letting others tell her stories, while Lucia suggests they play with reversed roles. Catalina reluctantly agrees to let Bernat be king while she is a viscountess, but negotiates to remain 'very important' and retain ownership of the toy horse.
